Curious to see how fellow Namibians were addressing issues that are directly or indirectly affecting them during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Accelerator Lab in collaboration with our partner Launch Namibia conceptualized a digital solution safari. The solution safari was a social media campaign that looked at COVID-19 related products and services developed or adapted by not only entrepreneurs but as well as community members in underserved areas.

Our aim with this campaign was to highlight entrepreneurs who are making a difference within their communities, we were specifically looking at entrepreneurs sharing useful information on COVID-19, gathering resources that can be donated to the less privileged or making innovative strides as entrepreneurs to ensure that they not only continue working but also inspiring others to follow suit. This digital safari was also a means to highlight and collate information on locally owned solutions outside of the entrepreneurship space. Our main way of engaging followers on social media was through a call to action where followers of both UNDP and Launch accounts were asked to submit information regarding community members who have developed COVID-19 specific solutions.

1.  Kaushiwetu Johannes came up with a hygiene hand-was system to aid the fight against the pandemic, his design can be customised to suit the needs of the community and it comes in various sizes. The design also allows for multiple people to use it at the same time.
2.Ingo Shangyenge through his start-up Inansa Investment has been manufacturing masks for essential staff as well as the public at large.
3.  Emmerancia Van Wyk has been providing nutritious meals to between 250 & 300 children daily who were formerly dependent on their school feeding schemes while educating them on COVID-19
4.  Linda Ndakolo whose start-up manufactures cleaning materials donated dishwashing liquid to over 500 beneficiaries living in an informal settlement in Windhoek.
5. Sylvanie Beukes alongside his partners has been developing sanitizing tools to aid in the fight of COVID-19 and future pathogenic threats to come.

,https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/5ac6a8fe-ddaf-4f25-8df0-e9840601a3bf/cb25dcaee385f83c620770488b9ecce9.jpg,Digital Solution Safari - SME's Response to COVID-19

This digital safari was also a means to highlight and collate information on locally owned solutions outside of the entrepreneurship space. 1.  Kaushiwetu Johannes came up with a hygiene hand-was system to aid the fight against the pandemic, his design can be customised to suit the needs of the community and it comes in various sizes. The design also allows for multiple people to use it at the same time.
2.Ingo Shangyenge through his start-up Inansa Investment has been manufacturing masks for essential staff as well as the public at large.

1163,c-10,Theocentric Business solution,9/22/20,1/16/23,2,,,ZMB,2,salome.nakazwe@undp.org,Zambia,"Most households in Zambia that are connected to electricity use 100 Watts ordinary bulbs that consume a lot of energy and have a short life span. The business aims to supply domestic households in medium and low density residential areas with LED bulbs with a low wattage and long life span. This will result in low power usage at household level and saving of electricity, whose efficiency has greatly been affect by prolonged draughts since the country depends on hydro generated power.",,"Theocentric Business solution

Most households in Zambia that are connected to electricity use 100 Watts ordinary bulbs that consume a lot of energy and have a short life span. The business aims to supply domestic households in medium and low density residential areas with LED bulbs with a low wattage and long life span. This will result in low power usage at household level and saving of electricity, whose efficiency has greatly been affect by prolonged draughts since the country depends on hydro generated power.

1156,c-10,Fumpi Nutritional Flour,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,ZMB,2,salome.nakazwe@undp.org,Zambia,"Low nutrition levels have been observed particularly among children and women. Further, there has been growing numbers of patients with chronic diseases which require a well supplemented nutritional diet. This is made worse by the increased working hours that people engage in due to economic hardships. People then resolve to consuming junk foods which are unhealthy. On the other hand, most of the nutritious local raw materials are exported to other countries and are later sold on the Zambian market as expensive finished products.",,"Fumpi Nutritional Flour

Low nutrition levels have been observed particularly among children and women. Further, there has been growing numbers of patients with chronic diseases which require a well supplemented nutritional diet. This is made worse by the increased working hours that people engage in due to economic hardships. People then resolve to consuming junk foods which are unhealthy. On the other hand, most of the nutritious local raw materials are exported to other countries and are later sold on the Zambian market as expensive finished products.

Joyous Food Processors developed a porridge formulation, made from a combination of millet, soya beans, sorghum, rice, groundnuts and maize that can be consumed by people of all ages and of diverse economic status. The promoter believes people are what they eat. Nutrition does not mean satisfying hunger only but having a balance of nutrients and vitamins in order to promote physical and mental wellbeing. The Fumpi flour makes a porridge that ensures that people have a balanced diet and live healthier lives.

1152,c-10,El Chipo hand Sanitizer,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,ZMB,2,salome.nakazwe@undp.org,Zambia,"Public places have been found to be challenging places to maintain high hygiene practices namely market places, schools and hospitals among others. Further, there is limited access to clean water and soap that can be used to ensure cleanliness. Certain environments are very busy thus making it difficult for people to remember to wash their hands as often as they should. The result of this is the spreading of communicable diseases and that increases pressure on the already congested health facilities especially in the context of COVID-19",,"El Chipo hand Sanitizer

Public places have been found to be challenging places to maintain high hygiene practices namely market places, schools and hospitals among others. Further, there is limited access to clean water and soap that can be used to ensure cleanliness. Certain environments are very busy thus making it difficult for people to remember to wash their hands as often as they should. The result of this is the spreading of communicable diseases and that increases pressure on the already congested health facilities especially in the context of COVID-19

El-Chipo hand sanitizer is a locally developed hand sanitizer using organic products. This is a powerful germ killing product which kills 99.5% of bacteria on contact and is made from natural ingredients extracted from organically grown plants. The use of locally sourced organic materials, makes the product affordable and easily accessible to low income earners.

1151,c-10,Cassava Value Chain Project,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,ZMB,2,salome.nakazwe@undp.org,Zambia,"Cassava is increasingly being used for different purposes including in the processing of leather industry, paper production, glue production and ethanol production. This provides opportunities for small scale farmers to provide the cassava, which in some parts of the country is grown in great quantities.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/8f6e5741-5556-46be-b6dc-6f536a09fba8/86f5f2ae9483eba9ce9b486c0de192e4.jpg,"Cassava Value Chain Project

Cassava is increasingly being used for different purposes including in the processing of leather industry, paper production, glue production and ethanol production. This provides opportunities for small scale farmers to provide the cassava, which in some parts of the country is grown in great quantities.

The innovation has designed a value chain that will link small scale cassava farmers to the market, while ensuring the farmers benefit from the value chain. The model will provide a stable market for cassava and promote cassava farming as a business.

1144,c-3,Green Slabs creating paving from plastic,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,ZWE,2,sharleen.moyo@undp.org,Zimbabwe,Greenslabs is a Bulawayo based startup that manufactures sidewalk paving slabs and decking from recycled plastic.,https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/4e27430b-9d20-4cef-a6f2-1743af0e5ef8/2684a4a463776c78d5f11451d65c8c5e.jpg,"Green Slabs creating paving from plastic
Greenslabs is a Bulawayo based startup that manufactures sidewalk paving slabs and decking from recycled plastic.

Green Slabs considers the problem of plastic waste in Zimbabwe. Plastic litter causes an unhealthy environment for pedestrians who use public spaces. The start up creates community clean up campaigns to collect this litter that forms an ingredient in the slabs they manufacture. Green slabs uses different technologies to make pavement slabs from recycled material, particularly plastic and glass and or rubber, in pursuit of a cleaner Bulawayo.

1138,c-20,The ProFoodApp,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,NAM,2,omagano.kankondi@undp.org,Namibia,"The ProFoodApp digitizes Namibia’s local and traditional food system flows thereby providing mapping, visualization and monitoring capacity to allow food to be easily located and procured at the local and regional levels and distributed to the end beneficiary in a more transparent and equitable manner.

The App acts as a “one-stop-shop approach” for local small-scale producers (e.g. women cooperatives & single producers) to procurement hubs and partners (e.g. Government, Semi-Government, Food aid programmes; Private sector) to end users (e.g. consumers and distributors of food parcels) and to end clients (e.g. beneficiaries).",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/5ac6a8fe-ddaf-4f25-8df0-e9840601a3bf/2345d40647515c1c2e7781dce9060f08.png,"The ProFoodApp

The ProFoodApp digitizes Namibia’s local and traditional food system flows thereby providing mapping, visualization and monitoring capacity to allow food to be easily located and procured at the local and regional levels and distributed to the end beneficiary in a more transparent and equitable manner.

The App acts as a “one-stop-shop approach” for local small-scale producers (e.g. women cooperatives & single producers) to procurement hubs and partners (e.g. Government, Semi-Government, Food aid programmes; Private sector) to end users (e.g. consumers and distributors of food parcels) and to end clients (e.g. beneficiaries).

1137,c-36,Plastic Bottle House ,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,TZA,2,ghati.horombe@undp.org,Tanzania,"AfriCraft joined hands with FEMINA and NipeFagio to create an information center for environmental care at Coco Beach in Dar es salaam. In view of the immense problem of pollution of the ocean by plastic waste the center was built out of plastic bottles, transforming plastic bottles into useful products.

AfriCraft joined hands with FEMINA and NipeFagio to create an information center for environmental care at Coco Beach in Dar es salaam. In view of the immense problem of pollution of the ocean by plastic waste the center was built out of plastic bottles, transforming plastic bottles into useful products.

1134,c-20,Re-blocking And Co-Production of Informal Settlements- Freedom Square,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,NAM,2,omagano.kankondi@undp.org,Namibia,"Freedom Square is one of the oldest informal settlements in Gobabis, Namibia and a pilot project for the implementation of the Flexible Land Tenure (FLT) system. This system allows for the creation of alternative forms of titling, which can eventually be upgraded to freehold titles. The pilot is a cooperation between the Municipality of Gobabis and the Shack Dwellers Federation of Namibia (SDFN), the Namibia Housing Action Group (NHAG) and the Namibia University of Science and Technology (NUST).  The project is motivated by an agenda of 'inclusive cities': through close collaboration with existing residents in the area, the process of land delivery is expedited and turned into an exercise of making inhabitants the drivers in the improvement of their living conditions. ",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/5ac6a8fe-ddaf-4f25-8df0-e9840601a3bf/7fda5fe32ba61e9883631b798edbf2ca.jpg,"Re-blocking And Co-Production of Informal Settlements- Freedom Square

Freedom Square is one of the oldest informal settlements in Gobabis, Namibia and a pilot project for the implementation of the Flexible Land Tenure (FLT) system. This system allows for the creation of alternative forms of titling, which can eventually be upgraded to freehold titles. The pilot is a cooperation between the Municipality of Gobabis and the Shack Dwellers Federation of Namibia (SDFN), the Namibia Housing Action Group (NHAG) and the Namibia University of Science and Technology (NUST).  The project is motivated by an agenda of 'inclusive cities': through close collaboration with existing residents in the area, the process of land delivery is expedited and turned into an exercise of making inhabitants the drivers in the improvement of their living conditions.

1133,c-10,Rosa Solar Stoves,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,ZMB,2,salome.nakazwe@undp.org,Zambia,Over reliance on electric powered stoves; and fire wood and charcoal from the trees. The three common sources of energy have a negative impact on the environment.,,"Rosa Solar Stoves
Over reliance on electric powered stoves; and fire wood and charcoal from the trees. The three common sources of energy have a negative impact on the environment.

The Innovation is a Fresnel-style Solar Stove in which a lens focuses concentrated sunlight onto a mirror, the mirror reflects the beam of solar energy onto a cooking area where heat is used for cooking. The innovation is a renewable and environmentally friendly source of energy that once implemented will contribute significantly to reducing the demand on charcoal and also provide an alternative energy source for household cooking. It can contribute to reduced electricity consumption and mitigate negative impact on climate.

1130,c-10,Fertilizer Applicator,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,ZMB,2,salome.nakazwe@undp.org,Zambia,"The application of fertilizer especially by subsistence farmers is a very long and tedious process with potential to cause long health ailments. The process also lacks standardization in the amounts of fertilizers each plant receives. To ease and increase efficiency in the application of

fertilizer by subsistence farmers, an applicator was designed to speed application of fertilizers in large fields and is easy to easy to carry since the fertilizer is carried in a correctly measured quantities in a chamber as one does not need to keep going to refill basins (which are commonly used) every now and then from a sack.",,"Fertilizer Applicator

The application of fertilizer especially by subsistence farmers is a very long and tedious process with potential to cause long health ailments. The process also lacks standardization in the amounts of fertilizers each plant receives. To ease and increase efficiency in the application of

fertilizer by subsistence farmers, an applicator was designed to speed application of fertilizers in large fields and is easy to easy to carry since the fertilizer is carried in a correctly measured quantities in a chamber as one does not need to keep going to refill basins (which are commonly used) every now and then from a sack.

1129,c-29,Ndovu Care Project - A solution to human-wildlife conflict,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,KEN,2,victor.awuor@undp.org,Kenya,"Developed by 17-year-old Sandra Maryanne, the Ndovu Care device offers a solution to human-wildlife conflict, a common phenomenon to communities living adjacent to Tsavo National Park which compromises the food and economic security of subsistence farmers. The portable device consists of a GSM card, a motion detector, a warning light and a siren. The gadget can detect an elephant at a radius of 180 meters after which it sends alerts to the Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS) as well as villagers, preparing them to act before the animals start destroying crops or making their way to habited areas. The warning messages are sent to individuals whose phones are linked to the GSM card. The sensors are capable of detecting the presence of an elephant and immediately alerting people by setting off flash lights and a siren, besides sending warning messages to KWS and villagers' phones.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/25020757-2ff6-4a23-831d-54fa05d4d184/5f4bc57b20bfa5894456b8e83092776d.jpg,"Ndovu Care Project - A solution to human-wildlife conflict

Developed by 17-year-old Sandra Maryanne, the Ndovu Care device offers a solution to human-wildlife conflict, a common phenomenon to communities living adjacent to Tsavo National Park which compromises the food and economic security of subsistence farmers. The portable device consists of a GSM card, a motion detector, a warning light and a siren. The gadget can detect an elephant at a radius of 180 meters after which it sends alerts to the Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS) as well as villagers, preparing them to act before the animals start destroying crops or making their way to habited areas. The warning messages are sent to individuals whose phones are linked to the GSM card. The sensors are capable of detecting the presence of an elephant and immediately alerting people by setting off flash lights and a siren, besides sending warning messages to KWS and villagers' phones.
sdgs: Decent work and economic growth

1128,c-10,Smart Energy Stove,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,ZMB,2,salome.nakazwe@undp.org,Zambia,Almost all electrified households in Zambia use resistive electric cookers for their cooking .This technology uses a lot of energy especially that there is a national electricity deficit and high domestic electricity tariffs. It offers opportunities to reduce electricity bills and save energy.,,"Smart Energy Stove

Almost all electrified households in Zambia use resistive electric cookers for their cooking .This technology uses a lot of energy especially that there is a national electricity deficit and high domestic electricity tariffs. It offers opportunities to reduce electricity bills and save energy.

Smart energy stove is a smart, energy efficient and safe cooking technology that can significantly reduce households’ electricity bills and promote safety in homes. The stove heats up quickly when switched while showing no red heat signal on the cooking tile. The stove includes a sensor which detects when not in use and automatically switches off.

Agripredict’s Information Communication Technology (ICT) application  addresses lack of access to timely information on farming conditions, weather, pests and their control measures. It's a mobile Application that gives timely information on farming conditions, weather, pests and provides agricultural advice to users.

The App offers farmers an easy-to-use way to diagnose plant diseases, predict weather patterns, identify pests and provide advice on general agricultural related topics. It offers benefits of improved yields, easy to diagnose plant diseases at an early stage to help improve a farmer's planning for their crops

1125,c-10,Disolpit - Pit latrine Disinfecting Powder,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,ZMB,2,salome.nakazwe@undp.org,Zambia,"Most households in peri urban and rural areas are not connected to the main sewerage lines that facilitate efficient and adequate waste disposal. This has led to some households relying on the use of pit latrines as a means of human waste (faecal matter) disposal. These pit latrines are buried when full and another site located for a new one. The pollution, health concerns and environmental degradation of this activity leaves much to be desired.

Most households in peri urban and rural areas are not connected to the main sewerage lines that facilitate efficient and adequate waste disposal. This has led to some households relying on the use of pit latrines as a means of human waste (faecal matter) disposal. These pit latrines are buried when full and another site located for a new one. The pollution, health concerns and environmental degradation of this activity leaves much to be desired.

The innovator has produced a non-toxic instant pit latrine dissolvent powder (Disolpit) which reduces the volume of human waste in pit latrines. The powder can be used both in pit latrines and septic tanks. With this reduction in volume, the number of pit latrines dug in peri-urban and rural areas would be reduced as the same one can still be used for a longer periods. The powder also helps to reduce bad smells associated with pit latrines as it rapidly digests waste assuring easy pump-outs. It attacks and neutralizes fly larvae, kills bacteria and maggots; and is non hazardous to people, animals and water bodies.

1120,c-10,Anti - Army Worm,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,ZMB,2,salome.nakazwe@undp.org,Zambia,For the past four years farmers in Zambia have experienced crop attacks by army worms. This problem has resulted into poor harvest thereby posing a threat to food security in the Country especially for the rural population that is highly dependent on small scale farming for their livelihoods and food security.,https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/8f6e5741-5556-46be-b6dc-6f536a09fba8/f09dc5a78c3ffbdd765cfd8767fef485.png,"Anti - Army Worm

For the past four years farmers in Zambia have experienced crop attacks by army worms. This problem has resulted into poor harvest thereby posing a threat to food security in the Country especially for the rural population that is highly dependent on small scale farming for their livelihoods and food security.
The innovation provides a chemical liquid that farmers can use to kill Army worms that are prone to attack the country's staple crop - maize

1119,c-10,BUMI Project ,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,ZMB,2,salome.nakazwe@undp.org,Zambia,"Many women suffer from gynecological diseases caused by poor menstrual hygiene and low-quality pads. Giving women access to high-quality sanitary products can help prevent diseases and can positively impact their health, lives and livelihoods.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/8f6e5741-5556-46be-b6dc-6f536a09fba8/2df9ad6721615950e9cce137f9a4ae41.jpg,"BUMI Project

Many women suffer from gynecological diseases caused by poor menstrual hygiene and low-quality pads. Giving women access to high-quality sanitary products can help prevent diseases and can positively impact their health, lives and livelihoods.

Bumi, which means life is a line of high-quality, affordable sanitary pads for girls and women. The innovation offer an innovative, quality sanitary pad that comes in 4 versions with 6 layers of protection and anion technology, Bumi pads offer dry, breathable and superior comfort during menstrual periods, a good development especially for women and girls living in rural areas where access to modern pads is a challenge.

1118,c-10,Greenbelt Energy and Trash for Cash,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,ZMB,2,salome.nakazwe@undp.org,Zambia,"Majority households in Zambia use Charcoal as a primary source of cooking/heating energy leading to deforestation, environmental degradation and this affects the climate. This has created an opportunity for investment in bio energy as an alternative source of energy to charcoal from the trees. ",,"Greenbelt Energy and Trash for Cash

Majority households in Zambia use Charcoal as a primary source of cooking/heating energy leading to deforestation, environmental degradation and this affects the climate. This has created an opportunity for investment in bio energy as an alternative source of energy to charcoal from the trees.

Greenbelt Energy has designed a smart renewable gas cooker that that is powered by biogas generated from animal waste and bio waste as a safe cooking gas and for generation of electricity while Trash for Cash uses has built a digester in one of the low cost residential areas to produce biogas as for the communities

She formed her own company  called Libe Green Innovation Co. Ltd. The company is dedicated to developing sustainable solutions to plastic pollution in the country through plastic waste collection, segregation, treatment and recycling into useful flakes consumed by manufacturing industries. The company has so far employed 10 people and has recently launched a new initiative called after event waste collectors.

They collect raw materials, mainly organic waste from different places in Arusha and Kilimanjaro regions includes different Argo fibers like wheat straw, rice straw, rice husk, hay, jute stick, groundnut shell, energy grasses (miscanthus, elephant grass, switchgrass), Seed husks, corn cobs, corn Stover, energy cane, sugar cane bagasse, and mustard, Stalk, coir pith, etc. Cotton stalk, bamboo, grapevine clippings, fruit tree clippings, coffee shrubs, Olive pits, coffee husk, peanut shells, and all other types of nut shells; Tobacco waste, used coffee grinds, dried tomato vines; Recycled paper, cardboard, Dried animal droppings, dried sludge from wastewater treatment plants and carbonize these organic farm waste and shape them to form briquettes charcoal.

1112,c-29,Water hyacinth cake,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,KEN,2,victor.awuor@undp.org,Kenya,"Jack Oyugi, founded Biofit Agritech, a company that harnesses the invasive water hyacinth and converts it into an animal food supplement. The invasive weed which first appeared in Africa in the early 1900s made its way to Lake Victoria where it has closed off fishing routes and provided a new habitat for disease-carrying mosquitoes.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/25020757-2ff6-4a23-831d-54fa05d4d184/4a19a0872f1b0fc8e809be123c3387f1.jpg,"Water hyacinth cake

Jack Oyugi, founded Biofit Agritech, a company that harnesses the invasive water hyacinth and converts it into an animal food supplement. The invasive weed which first appeared in Africa in the early 1900s made its way to Lake Victoria where it has closed off fishing routes and provided a new habitat for disease-carrying mosquitoes.

The water hyacinth is steam boiled, dried, crushed and fermented to make a powder, which is then mixed with minerals and energy-rich materials like maize bran to make an affordable feed sold at a fraction of the price of soya feed. The byproducts from making the feed can also be sold as fertilizers. The company employs the fishermen as harvesters as they can no longer fish because the hyacinth levels are so high.

1107,c-29,"Shamba Records - Digital tool linking farmers to markets

,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,KEN,2,victor.awuor@undp.org,Kenya,George Maina founded Shamba Records, an agritech startup that uses Blockchain and AI to collect small scale farmers' production data, link them to markets, process their payments and connect them to credit alternatives. So far, Shamba Records has digitized more than 6,000 small scale farmers and their respective cooperatives. Shamba Records solves the challenges of records manipulation, delayed payments, credit score and inadequate farming information.

1102,c-29,Custom electric wheelchairs,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,KEN,2,victor.awuor@undp.org,Kenya,"The custom electric wheelchairs are made from scarp materials collected from junkyards and can withstand potholes and untarmacked roads. His dislike for petrol led him to consider green energy. Most of his wheelchairs are made of 90% recycled materials, the only imported part is the battery management system.

The custom electric wheelchairs are made from scarp materials collected from junkyards and can withstand potholes and untarmacked roads. The innovator, Lincoln Wamae, was inspired to develop these wheelchairs after witnessing heartbreaking scenes of persons with disabilities struggling to board public service vehicles during a downpour in the Central Business District. His dislike for petrol led him to consider green energy. Most of his wheelchairs are made of 90% recycled materials, the only imported part is the battery management system.

1100,c-29,Solar powered mobile milk cooler,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,KEN,2,victor.awuor@undp.org,Kenya,"Farmers in Kenya's West Pokot County struggled to sell their milk as it often got spoilt during transportation. The solution developed by an informatics graduate was a solar powered milk cooler designed to fit onto donkeys and motorcycles. The invention uses aluminium tanks as a cooling system which are connected to a solar panel. It also has a milk PH test kit, an automatic weighing scale and a customized dairy co-operative management application which links the machine and the cooperative society. The machine allows a farmer to keep milk for maximum of three days without going bad. The app automatically collects milk quality and quantity data and relays it to the cooperative's payroll after computing the monthly total collections and relays the same information to the farmer through SMS. ",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/25020757-2ff6-4a23-831d-54fa05d4d184/95e42f0aaf624d585675bfb18bd463eb.jpg,"Solar powered mobile milk cooler

Farmers in Kenya's West Pokot County struggled to sell their milk as it often got spoilt during transportation. The solution developed by an informatics graduate was a solar powered milk cooler designed to fit onto donkeys and motorcycles. The invention uses aluminium tanks as a cooling system which are connected to a solar panel. It also has a milk PH test kit, an automatic weighing scale and a customized dairy co-operative management application which links the machine and the cooperative society. The machine allows a farmer to keep milk for maximum of three days without going bad. The app automatically collects milk quality and quantity data and relays it to the cooperative's payroll after computing the monthly total collections and relays the same information to the farmer through SMS.
sdgs: Decent work and economic growth

1099,c-10,"Cholera Detection, Prevention and cure",9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,ZMB,2,salome.nakazwe@undp.org,Zambia,"Cholera outbreaks in Zambia mainly affect Lusaka and the other densely populated peri-urban areas. The outbreak is mainly due to unsafe drinking water and faecal contamination. The affected areas are usually high density areas which mostly do not have running water, mainly have pit latrines and shallow wells where the water can easily be contaminated.
The Innovation seeks to detect, prevent and cure cholera cases faster.
·       Reduced Cholera related deaths",,"Cholera Detection, Prevention and cure

Cholera outbreaks in Zambia mainly affect Lusaka and the other densely populated peri-urban areas. The outbreak is mainly due to unsafe drinking water and faecal contamination. The affected areas are usually high density areas which mostly do not have running water, mainly have pit latrines and shallow wells where the water can easily be contaminated.
The Innovation seeks to detect, prevent and cure cholera cases faster.

1098,c-29,Recycling single use plastic water bottles,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,KEN,2,victor.awuor@undp.org,Kenya,"Lack of proper waste disposal mechanisms has led to littering of single use plastic in Wajir town, located in the Northern part of Kenya. ",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/25020757-2ff6-4a23-831d-54fa05d4d184/cdb6b7d5350263c0d80a9bf7d13e5cba.jpg,"Recycling single use plastic water bottles
Lack of proper waste disposal mechanisms has led to littering of single use plastic in Wajir town, located in the Northern part of Kenya.

One resident in this town has devised ingenious ways of recycling single use plastic water bottles to mitigate the challenges brought about by poor means to dispose the bottles by recycling them. He has made his fence out of the plastics and uses the same to harvest rainwater.

1097,c-10,Floating Hydro Kinetic Power Plants,9/21/20,1/16/23,2,,,ZMB,2,salome.nakazwe@undp.org,Zambia,Zambia has in the past few years experienced high levels of load shedding due to challenges with the hydro electric supply that powers almost the whole country and coupled by frequent draughts that have hit the region resulting in low water levels at the Dam that is shared with Zimbabwe. ,https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/8f6e5741-5556-46be-b6dc-6f536a09fba8/73b76d9d3855ade18fd6261ed8c15193.jpg,"Floating Hydro Kinetic Power Plants

Zambia has in the past few years experienced high levels of load shedding due to challenges with the hydro electric supply that powers almost the whole country and coupled by frequent draughts that have hit the region resulting in low water levels at the Dam that is shared with Zimbabwe.

The innovation is aimed providing energy solution using low cost sources. It is adapted from lessons learnt from India and promises to ensure low cost and efficient turbines placed on shallow surfaces are able to generate power. This will ensure a smart solution to the energy challenges being faced in the country.

1091,c-29,Boiled eggs and smokies trolley: On-the-go snacks business,9/20/20,1/16/23,2,,,KEN,2,victor.awuor@undp.org,Kenya,"This egg/ smokie trolley is locally made out of strong metal and glass that can withstand harsh weather. It is designed to keep the food hot in a hygienic way. The lower compartment accommodates a cookstove which not only keeps the eggs and smokies hot but also makes them tastier. The three-wheels and a handle ensure ease of movement over various surfaces as vendors search of customers. This trolley acts as both a display with partition for eggs and sausages and smokies. It is also spacious enough to accommodate a lot of eggs and sausages.  Customers at bus stops, marketplaces and bars are the main consumers of the snacks. The business is favored  by most traders as it requires low capital to start. The biggest expense goes into buying a trolley. Those who cannot afford to buy the trolley have an option of renting one. ",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/25020757-2ff6-4a23-831d-54fa05d4d184/3ed53ed70daa2b862d8cb1dc8a6a297d.jpg,"Boiled eggs and smokies trolley: On-the-go snacks business

The three-wheels and a handle ensure ease of movement over various surfaces as vendors search of customers. This trolley acts as both a display with partition for eggs and sausages and smokies. It is also spacious enough to accommodate a lot of eggs and sausages.  Customers at bus stops, marketplaces and bars are the main consumers of the snacks. 1072,c-20,Homeless People mobile application ,9/19/20,1/16/23,2,,,NAM,2,omagano.kankondi@undp.org,Namibia,"Homeless people and people living in informal settlements continue to be left behind in terms of receiving social benefits and services. Often, because they do not have a permanent shelter or live under difficult conditions. At present it is challenging for government to keep track of how many people to serve and adequately plan for benefits the underserved are entitled. Homeless People’s Mobile App is a tech solution which registers information of people in order to receive certain benefits. Beneficiaries are registered through a community health/extension worker and they are given a card encoded with a QR code and the card has a lanyard which they use to claim benefits. The QR code is a unique identifier of a beneficiary. Once the card is scanned, data such as geo-location, the person’s demographic information, health information and benefits received (e.g. Food package, soup kitchen credit, shelter and so on) is captured and stored in a central database. The solution is first going to be used to register an estimated 900 homeless people in Khomas region (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khomas_Region) and then scaled up to be implemented in at least one other regions (Erongo https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erongo_Region).",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/5ac6a8fe-ddaf-4f25-8df0-e9840601a3bf/3eb0c61554dd2fcce91d398af619dc94.jpg,"Homeless People mobile application

Homeless people and people living in informal settlements continue to be left behind in terms of receiving social benefits and services. Often, because they do not have a permanent shelter or live under difficult conditions. At present it is challenging for government to keep track of how many people to serve and adequately plan for benefits the underserved are entitled. Homeless People’s Mobile App is a tech solution which registers information of people in order to receive certain benefits. Beneficiaries are registered through a community health/extension worker and they are given a card encoded with a QR code and the card has a lanyard which they use to claim benefits. The QR code is a unique identifier of a beneficiary. Once the card is scanned, data such as geo-location, the person’s demographic information, health information and benefits received (e.g. Food package, soup kitchen credit, shelter and so on) is captured and stored in a central database. The solution is first going to be used to register an estimated 900 homeless people in Khomas region (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khomas_Region) and then scaled up to be implemented in at least one other regions (Erongo https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erongo_Region).

1071,c-20,Connecting Informal Vendors to an e-commerce platform ,9/19/20,1/16/23,2,,,NAM,2,omagano.kankondi@undp.org,Namibia,"In order to secure the livelihoods of traders in the informal sector, the CO, through its Accelerator Lab, launched an e-commerce pilot project in May 2020 to connect informal traders with consumers, especially given the break in supply chains during the lockdown implemented to curb the spread of the coronavirus. (www.tambula.com). The pilot aimed to assess how market vendors whose only clients were walk-ins, could reach a wider range of customers via an online shopping platform.

After a three month pilot in the central region (Khomas  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khomas_Region), the digital solution is expanding to a second region (Erongo  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erongo_Region).
Given the success of the pilot to date, UNDP and the project counterpart has negotiated with an additional 15 vendors who have signed up in the Erongo region to participate in the expanded pilot.

Mapper: Omagano Kankondi",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/5ac6a8fe-ddaf-4f25-8df0-e9840601a3bf/2987202519ab4706267b13fc63e24e2b.jpg,"Connecting Informal Vendors to an e-commerce platform

In order to secure the livelihoods of traders in the informal sector, the CO, through its Accelerator Lab, launched an e-commerce pilot project in May 2020 to connect informal traders with consumers, especially given the break in supply chains during the lockdown implemented to curb the spread of the coronavirus. (www.tambula.com). The pilot aimed to assess how market vendors whose only clients were walk-ins, could reach a wider range of customers via an online shopping platform.

After a three month pilot in the central region (Khomas  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khomas_Region), the digital solution is expanding to a second region (Erongo  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erongo_Region).
Given the success of the pilot to date, UNDP and the project counterpart has negotiated with an additional 15 vendors who have signed up in the Erongo region to participate in the expanded pilot.

1067,c-22,Wholistic Education with life skills by Jangu Tusome,9/19/20,1/16/23,2,,,UGA,2,hadijah.nabbale@undp.org,Uganda,"Wholistic Education with life skill Sponsorships programmes for vulnerable Ugandan Orphans
Jangu Tusome translated from Luganda means: “Come let us study”
Jangu Tusome is a local Ugandan community based organization born in SINA and a partner to Jangu e.V. in Germany for educational sponsorships of orphans in Uganda throughout high school.
If you are interested in sponsoring a child through Jangu Tusome, please find more details here.

Since 2014, many of the former sponsored students started to engage in the work of Jangu e.V. to support their younger brothers and sister of the Kankobe Children’s Home. Being sponsored as a child, they now sponsor others and create an outstanding, sustainable cycle to tackle the social problems of Uganda. Nowadays, Jangu e.V. doesn’t only provide sponsorships and life guidance to orphans from Kankobe but includes many other project. Thus, in 2016 former sponsored students founded “Jangu Tusome”  which stands for the coordination of the sponsorship program in Uganda. Together they take on essential roles like paying our partner schools, handing out scholastic materials and supporting the sponsored students in every day life. The fact, that the children of the Kankobe Children’s Home receive a proper education and are able to grow to mature and independent humans is in many ways owed to the work of the “Jangu Tusome” Team.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/40119c91-a65d-46a8-b910-383024e2ca6c/43684450c6039b5819cbde751f6b22f4.png,"Wholistic Education with life skills by Jangu Tusome
Wholistic Education with life skill Sponsorships programmes for vulnerable Ugandan Orphans
Jangu Tusome translated from Luganda means: “Come let us study”
Jangu Tusome is a local Ugandan community based organization born in SINA and a partner to Jangu e.V. in Germany for educational sponsorships of orphans in Uganda throughout high school.
If you are interested in sponsoring a child through Jangu Tusome, please find more details here.

Since 2014, many of the former sponsored students started to engage in the work of Jangu e.V. to support their younger brothers and sister of the Kankobe Children’s Home. Being sponsored as a child, they now sponsor others and create an outstanding, sustainable cycle to tackle the social problems of Uganda. Nowadays, Jangu e.V. doesn’t only provide sponsorships and life guidance to orphans from Kankobe but includes many other project. Thus, in 2016 former sponsored students founded “Jangu Tusome”  which stands for the coordination of the sponsorship program in Uganda. Together they take on essential roles like paying our partner schools, handing out scholastic materials and supporting the sponsored students in every day life. The fact, that the children of the Kankobe Children’s Home receive a proper education and are able to grow to mature and independent humans is in many ways owed to the work of the “Jangu Tusome” Team.

1064,c-22,Re-using plastic bottle for construction of houses by Upcycle Africa,9/19/20,1/16/23,2,,,UGA,2,hadijah.nabbale@undp.org,Uganda,"Plastic Bottle Constructions of houses as a means of Upcycling
Winner of the 2020 UN-Habitat Scroll of Honour award, Upcycle Africa upcycles plastic bottles by building houses.

There are over 150 Million Tonnes of Plastic already in the oceans. Every year, eight million tonnes of plastic waste end up in oceans and lakes. Experts predict that there will be more plastic than fish in oceans by 2050. And yet, the more waste we generate, the more waste we need to dispose off, but how? Plastic waste is not the only challenge we have in Uganda and Africa as a whole. Housing is still very expensive especially for people living in slums and low income areas. In Kampala, homes in slums are usually filled up with water when it rains, damaging property and making it difficult for people to live decently and yet, dignified housing is expensive considering that these families earn an average of $40 as monthly income.

Upcycle Africa protects the environment and promotes innovative mind-set while empowering youth. Through up-cycling plastic waste we train our local communities in Uganda especially the disadvantaged youth to protect the environment. Bottles replace environmentally unfriendly bricks, which are burnt for days promoting deforestation. Plastic bottles are collected and compacted with soil, making the houses very cost effective and affordable. Furthermore, the buildings are durable, buffer heat and are earthquake resistant. Upcycle Africa has constructed houses in different parts of Africa while creating employment opportunities for rural women and youths this has ensured economic empowerment for these women. These cash incentive allows low-income families to support their children with school fees. We also have a waste recovery system where we collect plastic waste from beaches, streets and bus stations ensuring clean and safe environments.

,https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/40119c91-a65d-46a8-b910-383024e2ca6c/0510deefcc17092998064acd2f47dbd5.jpg,Re-using plastic bottle for construction of houses by Upcycle Africa

Kyaffe is a Luganda word meaning ""ours"" which symbolizes communalism and working together as one. For the past three years we have been working relentlessly to empower and organize smallholders using the farmer ownership model and getting women increasingly more involved in our value chain.

1062,c-22,Mosquito repellant products from Lemongrass by Uganics,9/19/20,1/16/23,2,,,UGA,2,hadijah.nabbale@undp.org,Uganda,"Uganics is an organisation providing purely organic, mild scented mosquito repellent.

In Uganda, children below five years are the most affected with malaria. According to the Ugandan Ministry of Health, currently 90% of 100,000 recorded malaria deaths are children, especially from rural areas. The majority of rural communities do not have access to treated mosquito nets, and do not have access to preventive measures.

In Uganda, children below five years are the most affected with malaria. According to the Ugandan Ministry of Health, currently 90% of 100,000 recorded malaria deaths are children, especially from rural areas. The majority of rural communities do not have access to treated mosquito nets, and do not have access to preventive measures. The government of Uganda is investing efforts in the reduction of malaria by providing interventions like the distribution of mosquito nets, or spraying homes with DDT. Malaria cases still remain high because the solutions are not long lasting and mosquito nets are only effective during sleep time. DDT is raising also severe health concerns due to its chemical components.

Malaria is one of today’s major global health challenges and has been associated with slow socioeconomic development and poverty. Uganda has some of the highest reported malaria transmission rates in the world, with approximately 16 million cases reported in 2013 and over 100 000 deaths annually.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/40119c91-a65d-46a8-b910-383024e2ca6c/e4a2ee202f3b81b919dfd9e14b829a8c.jpg,"Mosquito repellant products from Lemongrass by Uganics
Uganics is an organisation providing purely organic, mild scented mosquito repellent.

In Uganda, children below five years are the most affected with malaria. According to the Ugandan Ministry of Health, currently 90% of 100,000 recorded malaria deaths are children, especially from rural areas. The majority of rural communities do not have access to treated mosquito nets, and do not have access to preventive measures.

In Uganda, children below five years are the most affected with malaria. According to the Ugandan Ministry of Health, currently 90% of 100,000 recorded malaria deaths are children, especially from rural areas. The majority of rural communities do not have access to treated mosquito nets, and do not have access to preventive measures. The government of Uganda is investing efforts in the reduction of malaria by providing interventions like the distribution of mosquito nets, or spraying homes with DDT. Malaria cases still remain high because the solutions are not long lasting and mosquito nets are only effective during sleep time. DDT is raising also severe health concerns due to its chemical components.

Malaria is one of today’s major global health challenges and has been associated with slow socioeconomic development and poverty. Uganda has some of the highest reported malaria transmission rates in the world, with approximately 16 million cases reported in 2013 and over 100 000 deaths annually.

1061,c-22,Biodegradable Fashion accessories by Ssuubi Designs,9/19/20,1/16/23,2,,,UGA,2,hadijah.nabbale@undp.org,Uganda,"Empowering marginalized youths in skills of fashion through upcycling waste and using environmentally friendly materials.

The company was founded in 2014 by Josephine Nakiyimba from western Uganda. The name is derived from the Luganda term for “hope”. We use materials that are available everywhere – because we upcycle waste. Out of paper we make beads, and plastic bottles are turned into bracelets and earrings. Bark cloth, being a completely natural product, is blended with colorful Kitenge fabric to become a biodegradable wallet. Bark cloth is the first cloth humans ever made thousands of years ago from the bark of the Mutuba Tree, home only in Uganda.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/40119c91-a65d-46a8-b910-383024e2ca6c/ce003d2184b6dfad8943e112df01c27e.png,"Biodegradable Fashion accessories by Ssuubi Designs
Empowering marginalized youths in skills of fashion through upcycling waste and using environmentally friendly materials.

The company was founded in 2014 by Josephine Nakiyimba from western Uganda. The name is derived from the Luganda term for “hope”. We use materials that are available everywhere – because we upcycle waste. Out of paper we make beads, and plastic bottles are turned into bracelets and earrings. Bark cloth, being a completely natural product, is blended with colorful Kitenge fabric to become a biodegradable wallet. Bark cloth is the first cloth humans ever made thousands of years ago from the bark of the Mutuba Tree, home only in Uganda.

1056,c-22,Online Science Classrooms by Sayans Academy,9/19/20,1/16/23,2,,,UGA,2,hadijah.nabbale@undp.org,Uganda,"Sayans Academy covers the gap between learning sciences and its real world application.

We are a providing digital STEM learning platform for secondary schools. This is an online classroom where students undergo tailored training, create collaborations, ask, share and access mentors/experts in given fields.

Sayans is a not for profit organization focused on transforming science and technology in Africa through education. It is started and managed by individuals experienced in the application of science, technology and business development.

Sayans supports students in African rural secondary schools experiment with and apply science to real life. We set up spaces within the network schools where students are engaged in hands-on workshops, nurture their creativity and problem solving skills by using science and technology to solve real life challenges and above all have FUN.

Sayans was established in 2016 initially supporting teachers embrace Project Based Learning in their classes. With previous learning, Sayans iterated since 2018 with a focus on working directly with students and supplementing the teachers through a Flipped Classroom Learning model.
Sayans is currently setting up in Mpigi, Uganda with a goal to grow exponentially to add more countries in Africa.
Students impacted 1000+. Sayans is finalizing a partnership agreement with Ministry of Education, Science, Technology and Sports to have scaled implementation in all secondary schools in the country.
Our promise is based on our core values. And every school and student who joins gets just that;
Resources for Do It Yourself projects
Our workshops span all STEM areas, basic ICT, including coding and programming and we got the right people and partnerships to make each workshop leave a wow moment in each student.

Our program is designed to supplement what teachers teach through a Flipped Classroom Model – students learn outside the class and class-time is used for discussions and review. This model is tested to leave great results both academic and outside the class.

We have a database of over 100 innovative teachers, engineers, doctors… both locally and internationally who are more than willing to share their knowledge with the students. These professionals use innovative analogies to create deeper and engraved understandings of science concepts.
Each Sayans center within a school is run by a Sayans fellow, a university science graduate who is well equipped to guide, empower and mentor each student.
Our team provides valuable information to support the decision and career choice making of the students. We have the right people in the right fields to give the right guidance.

Want to share your knowledge or give career guidance for secondary school students, commit a few hours of your time with us as an expert/teacher. We fit in your timeframe. Have an old laptop, book or any hands on tool you would love to give away? We do appreciate it. Is it a financial contribution? We shall use it to support more schools set up innovation labs.
Sayans Academy covers the gap between learning sciences and its real world application.

We are a providing digital STEM learning platform for secondary schools. This is an online classroom where students undergo tailored training, create collaborations, ask, share and access mentors/experts in given fields.

Sayans is a not for profit organization focused on transforming science and technology in Africa through education. It is started and managed by individuals experienced in the application of science, technology and business development.

Sayans supports students in African rural secondary schools experiment with and apply science to real life. We set up spaces within the network schools where students are engaged in hands-on workshops, nurture their creativity and problem solving skills by using science and technology to solve real life challenges and above all have FUN.

1050,c-22,Bio sand water filter by Tusafishe,9/19/20,1/16/23,2,,,UGA,2,hadijah.nabbale@undp.org,Uganda,"Bio sand water filters
Our focus is on eliminating Water borne diseases by providing plenty of safe water to both institutions

and households in a way that preserves our environment. In a country where keeping drinking water clean or even getting clean water in the first place is difficult, there are few communities that don’t face preventable illnesses like typhoid that come from these sources of water. Even pipes are not always safe. Traditionally, people then try and boil their water, which consumes a lot of charcoal and time. Then, the water is stored in pots and jerrycans, and if it wasn’t contamined during transport, bacteria will now easily enter.

This is a lot of effort for a small outcome. Tusafishe has inquired from the communities that there is a need for a better solution, and our solution is a simple one: Sand filters. Using the same principle as natural springs in the ground, it is simply a bucket filled with nothing but freshly ground granite. It filters particles, bacteria, even chemicals out of the water and makes it safe to drink. One small bucket filters up to 40 liters per day, enough for an average household. A large bucket has a capacity of 200 liters per day. And the more the filter is used, the more the material compacts – the water will get even cleaner over time. It’s „forever lasting“: The Tusafishe granite just needs to be washed and dried every few months and the bucket can be refilled right away.

1049,c-22,Social Rehabilitation for victims of sexual abuses by Totya (Fear not) Platform,9/19/20,1/16/23,2,,,UGA,2,hadijah.nabbale@undp.org,Uganda,"Totya Platform supports victims of sexual abuse overcome trauma and get justice. The Social Problem

In Uganda 78% of the primary school children and 82% of the secondary school students report having experienced sexual abuse at school (UNICEF 2013). According to the Annual Crime Report (2013) of the Uganda Police Force, close to 10,000 cases of defilement were reported in 2013, making it the second leading crime committed in Uganda. Astoundingly, only four percent of perpetrators have been convicted. The number of unreported cases are unknown but are estimated to be as high as even 50,000 per year. Tens of thousands of girls suffer in silence, while the perpetrators are not prosecuted. Like in my own case, it often happens within family settings and this is what makes it so difficult and often impossible for the victims to talk about. They do not want to be responsible for breaking the family apart or they fear the consequences of e.g. not receiving school fees or basic needs. The fear that no one will believe often leaves the victim to blame herself, even hate herself sometimes for the rest of their live or committing suicide. Without being able to speak about the events, girls end up being affected for life about the way they perceive themselves, relationships with men and lack of self-belief. Janet Aguti was one of the girls sexually abused as a child. For 17 years she did not find the courage to tell anyone. She started to see her past as strength rather than a subject of shame and Today, Janet Aguti is the founder and driving force of Totya Platform!

Totya Platform provides support to victims of sexual violence through Peer Groups, Life-Coaching- in person and online, as well as medical and legal support of severe cases. Anonymous interactions with survivors of sexual violence, who overcame sexual abuse themselves, enable users to speak about their experiences while receiving emotional care and self-help tools. Our service is free and available to those who were victims of sexual violence – no matter what type or by whom – in their childhood or as youths. Totya supports all questions and problems that have resulted from the sexual violence and its effects as an adult. Coaching sessions are absolutely confidential.

If you would wish to talk to Totya Platform, send a message (also WhatsApp) to (+256) (0)759 296 003 (internationally) or call the Free End Sexual Abuse Hotline: 080 0220630 (Uganda only. People who have successfully transformed the experiences are encouraged to find strength in speaking up, joining our campaigns online campaigns to break the taboo on speaking about sexual abuse. For continuous self-organized support among each other, self-help groups are initiated for the women, meeting regularly and in person",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/40119c91-a65d-46a8-b910-383024e2ca6c/75c2e1643bcfc11b7d3701873b15e72c.png,"Social Rehabilitation for victims of sexual abuses by Totya (Fear not) Platform

1046,c-22,Irrigation for Agriculture in Refugee Settlements by KilimOasis,9/19/20,1/16/23,2,,,UGA,2,hadijah.nabbale@undp.org,Uganda,"Transforming dry soils into fertile soils through irrigation in agriculture in refugee Settlements

KilimOasis is situated in the Nakivale Refugee Settlement in Uganda, which is home to over 100,000 refugees. Food rations given by the United Nations have been cut down to the bare minimum for survival due to the increase of refugees in Uganda (currently over 1,5 million) and families are malnourished.

The refugee settlement is situated around a vast lake and YesLife Scope is using a mobile water pump to make dry and infertile land suitable for agriculture. Currently, 12 families are trained in farming and watering their crops. The produce is partly consumed by the refugees to have a nutritious diet but about half of it is also sold to urban centres and Kampala. Profits are saved and after three seasons paid out to the families as start-up capital to start their own small-scale farm while new families are empowered.

,https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/40119c91-a65d-46a8-b910-383024e2ca6c/ed55260f6b57889fb871414cd517bf9f.png,Irrigation for Agriculture in Refugee Settlements by KilimOasis
Transforming dry soils into fertile soils through irrigation in agriculture in refugee Settlements

1041,c-22,Upcycling and Recycling of Plastic waste by Reform Africa,9/19/20,1/16/23,2,,,UGA,2,hadijah.nabbale@undp.org,Uganda,"Upcycling and Recylcing of Plastic Waste

Plastic waste disposal in Uganda is on the increase. It is estimated that 600 tonnes of plastic is disposed of in Uganda daily this is due to the rapid rate of emerging small scale producing companies competing with bigger companies to produce more plastic products hence increase in the accumulation of plastic waste.

Kampala city alone accounts for the vast chunk of plastic waste, which is littered all over the city and clogging sewage systems, according to the National Environment Management Authority. About 51% of the plastic garbage in the city is left uncollected and ends up in drainage channels, wetlands, natural watercourses, manholes, undeveloped plots and on the roadside. In the rural areas, it is a sad story; plastic garbage in most cases left to decompose on its own.
Reform Africa is changing this, we are transforming plastic waste into affordable, durable and waterproof bags.

,https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/40119c91-a65d-46a8-b910-383024e2ca6c/ffb084927a433aa96a594fa16ca78253.png,Upcycling and Recycling of Plastic waste by Reform Africa
Upcycling and Recylcing of Plastic Waste

1035,c-22,Upcycling old tarpaulins from aid-giving Agencies into bags and raincoats by  EcoDesigns,9/19/20,1/16/23,2,,,UGA,2,hadijah.nabbale@undp.org,Uganda,"Upcycling old aid tarpaulins into bags in the Bidibidi Refugee Settlement

EcoDesigns collects old tarpaulins from UNHCR or other aid agencies, which were given to arriving refugees for roofing. The sun is slowly destroying the plastic sheets and holes form and after a couple of years are thrown away. The social enterprise collects the sheets and uses the parts still in good condition as the base material for waterproof school bags for refugee children, handbags and shopping bags.

During COVID-19 outbreak, the enterprise started to quickly also produce face masks and was able to secure a large deal for the production of 50,000 masks through UNHCR, which are given out to the refugees in the camp.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/40119c91-a65d-46a8-b910-383024e2ca6c/fafb73cc07869c90d20cdf88acbb107d.png,"Upcycling old tarpaulins from aid-giving Agencies into bags and raincoats by  EcoDesigns
Upcycling old aid tarpaulins into bags in the Bidibidi Refugee Settlement

EcoDesigns collects old tarpaulins from UNHCR or other aid agencies, which were given to arriving refugees for roofing. The sun is slowly destroying the plastic sheets and holes form and after a couple of years are thrown away. The social enterprise collects the sheets and uses the parts still in good condition as the base material for waterproof school bags for refugee children, handbags and shopping bags.

During COVID-19 outbreak, the enterprise started to quickly also produce face masks and was able to secure a large deal for the production of 50,000 masks through UNHCR, which are given out to the refugees in the camp.

The KYN initiative is being implemented in one of the high density areas of the city supported by the Lusaka City Council. It is a community-led model called that aims to strengthen the social fabric of the community to address issues development issues namely waste management, Gender Based Violence (GBV), substance abuse.

In response to calls from the local Council to promote Clean Green and Health communities, the community discussed testing incentives to separate waste at source with the aim of reducing the amount of waste that ended up in the landfill.

,https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/a7850786-5bc4-4c64-9711-a0672b109fe3/e2c79a9d7e80a745b40d6971dff2f856.jpg,Stockage des légumes-feuilles dans un milieu humide
Conservation de la basilique dans un bocal d’eau.
« Les légumes feuilles sont arrosées régulièrement pour freiner leur vitesse de fanage et accroître leur durée de vie sur les étagères. » — vendeuse

841,c-22,GREEN – Uganda Inc - Reafforestation with the fast-growing varieties of trees,9/17/20,1/16/23,2,,,UGA,2,hadijah.nabbale@undp.org,Uganda,"Reafforestation. Our concept is to make tree planting be taken up as life saving service by humanity and must therefore be a duty of every living human being and must be free and voluntary. So we shall be coordinating activities of life saver volunteers
Our focus is to raise the fast growing varieties of trees both locally available and imported e.g. Clonal eucalyptus, Paulonia, Bamboos, Lira, Cassia, Neem etc,

These fast growing trees would quickly substitute the present wood product sources and thus alleviate the pressure on the naturally occurring wood sources allowing them to recover and rejuvenate effectively.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/40119c91-a65d-46a8-b910-383024e2ca6c/17beb9ba480617267883aa5d9aedebf5.png,"GREEN – Uganda Inc - Reafforestation with the fast-growing varieties of trees

Reafforestation. Our concept is to make tree planting be taken up as life saving service by humanity and must therefore be a duty of every living human being and must be free and voluntary. So we shall be coordinating activities of life saver volunteers
Our focus is to raise the fast growing varieties of trees both locally available and imported e.g. Clonal eucalyptus, Paulonia, Bamboos, Lira, Cassia, Neem etc,

These fast growing trees would quickly substitute the present wood product sources and thus alleviate the pressure on the naturally occurring wood sources allowing them to recover and rejuvenate effectively.
sdgs: Decent work and economic growth

This project therefore aims at greening northern Uganda through promotion of bamboo plantations, their value addition, and sustainable utilization to meet cooking and heating fuel needs of the people. Bamboo was chosen because of its high growth rate and biomass yield able to grow in most parts of the country which when sustainably managed and used for other valuable products besides cooking fuel shall reduce deforestation

839,c-22,Briquettes for poultry farming and household use by TWESIIME BRENDA ,9/17/20,1/16/23,2,,,UGA,2,hadijah.nabbale@undp.org,Uganda,"Briquettes are produced from agricultural waste mainly groundnut shells. they last for 6 hours and produce almost no smoke. using briquettes means that trees willnot be cut down to get firewood or charcoal hence reducing on the rate of deforastation. generally, our briquettes are alternative to charcoal and firewood.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/40119c91-a65d-46a8-b910-383024e2ca6c/059fa65983dcd47f58681dcc6a65b8a8.jpg,"Briquettes for poultry farming and household use by TWESIIME BRENDA

803,c-22,Supplying communities with LP gas for cooking by Wana Energy Solutions (WES) - LPG ,9/17/20,1/16/23,2,,,UGA,2,hadijah.nabbale@undp.org,Uganda,"Deforestation. Burning wood is dramatically less carbon-efficient than burning LPG. Wood consists of 50% fuel. The rest is molecularly-bound oxygen plus left-over moisture. Neither of these burns and vaporising the moisture wastes energy. LPG, by contrast, is all fuel. Per unit of delivered cooking heat, burning wood generates about five times the carbon of LPG. Switching from wood to LPG reduces cooking’s carbon emissions significantly. In Uganda, where much traditional cooking happens, switching from wood fuel to LPG cuts net-CO2 output to the atmosphere by 60%.

Switching 100 households from consuming 200 tonnes of harvested wood a year to consume instead 21.5 tonnes of LPG would save one hectare of forest each year. ",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/40119c91-a65d-46a8-b910-383024e2ca6c/7f904bb0e17c0c56983d949910a79a76.png,"Supplying communities with LP gas for cooking by Wana Energy Solutions (WES) - LPG

Deforestation. Burning wood is dramatically less carbon-efficient than burning LPG. Wood consists of 50% fuel. The rest is molecularly-bound oxygen plus left-over moisture. Neither of these burns and vaporising the moisture wastes energy. LPG, by contrast, is all fuel. Per unit of delivered cooking heat, burning wood generates about five times the carbon of LPG. Switching from wood to LPG reduces cooking’s carbon emissions significantly. In Uganda, where much traditional cooking happens, switching from wood fuel to LPG cuts net-CO2 output to the atmosphere by 60%.
Switching 100 households from consuming 200 tonnes of harvested wood a year to consume instead 21.5 tonnes of LPG would save one hectare of forest each year.

44,c-22,Ecoplastile Uganda- Roof tiles made out of recycled plastics,7/24/20,1/16/23,2,,,UGA,2,hadijah.nabbale@undp.org,Uganda,"EcoPlastile is a registered Ugandan social enterprise that allows thousands of slum dwellers to collect and use waste plastics as a form of financial resource in exchange for medical services and uses an innovative, chemical-free and energy-efficient technology called “waxy 2 technology” to transform post-consumer waste into plastic poles, lumbers and tiles which replaces expensive wooden timbers! thus reducing plastic plus marine pollution, deforestation rates, and the effects of climate change while improving access to health facilities especially for marginalized communities in developing countries",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/40119c91-a65d-46a8-b910-383024e2ca6c/402fc7346e86b4166dade78e12ba9ed9.jpg,"Ecoplastile Uganda- Roof tiles made out of recycled plastics

EcoPlastile is a registered Ugandan social enterprise that allows thousands of slum dwellers to collect and use waste plastics as a form of financial resource in exchange for medical services and uses an innovative, chemical-free and energy-efficient technology called “waxy 2 technology” to transform post-consumer waste into plastic poles, lumbers and tiles which replaces expensive wooden timbers! thus reducing plastic plus marine pollution, deforestation rates, and the effects of climate change while improving access to health facilities especially for marginalized communities in developing countries

32,c-8,Recycling of plastic waste into paving stones,7/14/20,1/16/23,2,,,MLI,2,countel.kanne@undp.org,Mali,"The CoGeNeT cooperative transforms plastic waste into paving stones. The objective of these young people is to promote sanitation in the neighbourhoods through the manufacture of ecological paving stones. The process consists of putting the plastic waste in a tank placed on the fire. When plastics are melted, sand is added and the whole thing is stirred. The paste obtained is placed in a mould and after a few minutes a 5 to 10cm thick paving stone is obtained.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/10d09daa-2a81-4b0a-a973-acf8450da112/269c6b82b492b2431b254cd7e66794a5.jpg,"Recycling of plastic waste into paving stones

The CoGeNeT cooperative transforms plastic waste into paving stones. The objective of these young people is to promote sanitation in the neighbourhoods through the manufacture of ecological paving stones. The process consists of putting the plastic waste in a tank placed on the fire. When plastics are melted, sand is added and the whole thing is stirred. The paste obtained is placed in a mould and after a few minutes a 5 to 10cm thick paving stone is obtained.

31,c-8,Energy production from waste plastics,7/14/20,1/16/23,2,,,MLI,2,countel.kanne@undp.org,Mali,"In search of local initiative, the team met an ambitious young man named Harouna who produces fuel and gas from plastic waste. From a device comprising two gas cylinders connected to each other and a barrel by a coupling, it produces fuel and gas after heating the plastic waste contained in the barrel to a high degree. Its objective is to eventually produce electricity from plastic waste.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/10d09daa-2a81-4b0a-a973-acf8450da112/2884893428d5d127384ddcee238ddea9.jpg,"Energy production from waste plastics

In search of local initiative, the team met an ambitious young man named Harouna who produces fuel and gas from plastic waste. From a device comprising two gas cylinders connected to each other and a barrel by a coupling, it produces fuel and gas after heating the plastic waste contained in the barrel to a high degree. Its objective is to eventually produce electricity from plastic waste.

This initiative is aesthetically pleasing while at the same time making a change in behaviour with respect to solid waste management. These recycled works of art are much appreciated by the visitors who go there.

27,c-8,"Production of biodegradable packaging with ""dah"" base (hibiscus)",7/14/20,1/16/23,2,,,MLI,2,countel.kanne@undp.org,Mali,"This initiative takes us to the interior of Mali, notably to the capital of the Kénédougou region of Sikasso, where a local company produces reusable and biodegradable bags made from hibiscus stalks.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/10d09daa-2a81-4b0a-a973-acf8450da112/86c7d5595a78f471cee06ae469e84303.jpg,"Production of biodegradable packaging with ""dah"" base (hibiscus)
This initiative takes us to the interior of Mali, notably to the capital of the Kénédougou region of Sikasso, where a local company produces reusable and biodegradable bags made from hibiscus stalks.

The company would like to substitute these dah (hibiscus) fibre bags for plastic bags in order to contribute to the fight against environmental pollution. It is also about connecting small producers to large companies.

26,c-8,Deposit Information Platform uncontrolled waste,7/14/20,1/16/23,2,,,MLI,2,countel.kanne@undp.org,Mali,"In the Faladiè SEMA-Bamako district of Faladiè, the Lab team discovered a small company called ""MAP Action"" which has developed an application that provides timely information on uncontrolled waste disposal sites. Also, this application allows the mapping of dumps and facilitates decision making regarding their management. It plans to mobilise statistical data in this sector using this application, which uses satellite and UAV images. This will make up for the lack of statistics on waste production in the city of Bamako.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/10d09daa-2a81-4b0a-a973-acf8450da112/4a4150aa1a6b3876056099d1ea337bf9.jpg,"Deposit Information Platform uncontrolled waste

In the Faladiè SEMA-Bamako district of Faladiè, the Lab team discovered a small company called ""MAP Action"" which has developed an application that provides timely information on uncontrolled waste disposal sites. Also, this application allows the mapping of dumps and facilitates decision making regarding their management. It plans to mobilise statistical data in this sector using this application, which uses satellite and UAV images. This will make up for the lack of statistics on waste production in the city of Bamako.

25,c-8,Sorting waste at source,7/14/20,1/16/23,2,,,MLI,2,countel.kanne@undp.org,Mali,"Sanuva is an initiative of young Malian expatriates who have created a small business whose aim is to contribute to a better management of plastic waste through a change in the behaviour of the population. It consists of carrying out awareness campaigns and providing the population with bins for sorting waste at source. The company receives the waste through the EIGs (Economic Interest Groups), then divides it into categories for export to different countries where it is processed in industry. In the experimental phase, this company plans to embrace the transformation of organic waste in the future.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/10d09daa-2a81-4b0a-a973-acf8450da112/ff6f02efcc8b31214ce65dce154650a6.jpg,"Sorting waste at source

Sanuva is an initiative of young Malian expatriates who have created a small business whose aim is to contribute to a better management of plastic waste through a change in the behaviour of the population. It consists of carrying out awareness campaigns and providing the population with bins for sorting waste at source. The company receives the waste through the EIGs (Economic Interest Groups), then divides it into categories for export to different countries where it is processed in industry. In the experimental phase, this company plans to embrace the transformation of organic waste in the future.

24,c-8,Shredding and export of solid plastic waste,7/14/20,1/16/23,2,,,MLI,2,countel.kanne@undp.org,Mali,"The search for local initiatives brought the Lab team to Banankoroni, a neighbourhood on the outskirts of Bamako. In this neighbourhood, we met a young, ambitious entrepreneur who has set up an informal solid plastic waste purchasing business. This company consists of a grinder and a washing basin. It buys solid plastic waste which is sorted, crushed, washed and bagged by the few men and women who work there. This plastic waste is destined for processing at the plant in Ghana.",https://acclabplatforms.blob.core.windows.net/solutions-mapping/uploads/sm/10d09daa-2a81-4b0a-a973-acf8450da112/fcb75420456bb8371a148a76558da9dc.jpg,"Shredding and export of solid plastic waste

The search for local initiatives brought the Lab team to Banankoroni, a neighbourhood on the outskirts of Bamako. In this neighbourhood, we met a young, ambitious entrepreneur who has set up an informal solid plastic waste purchasing business. This company consists of a grinder and a washing basin. It buys solid plastic waste which is sorted, crushed, washed and bagged by the few men and women who work there. This plastic waste is destined for processing at the plant in Ghana.
The entrepreneur wants to develop this business by recovering plastic waste because, according to him, the sanitation sector presents real economic opportunities.

In our quest for solutions in the #Acceleratorlab we came across with one wonderful recycling experience in Cabo Verde, which we’d like to share with you!

Santo Antão is the further Northwest island of the Cabo Verde archipelago. It’s an island known by its mountains, green valleys, rural tourism, trekking and delicious local food, but since 2017, Santo Antão has also became the heart of plastic recycling in Cabo Verde. This is the incredible story of Maria Teresa Segredo and the Netherlands Foundation “Amigos do Paúl” (Friends of Paúl).

Penedo is a small locality in the gateway to Janela area, after Santa Barbara tunnel for those traveling on the coastal road from the municipality of Porto Novo to Paúl. Arid, eminently a fishing village with some trade and few residents, Penedo is also the access to other touristic places in the region, like Ribeira and Fajã.

Since 2017 the area has gained another movement with the factory that is giving new life to plastics, turning them into tiles and helping to solve one of the environmental dramas in the country, which is the high use of plastic bottles ""PET"", which after use are thrown to the ground.

Each tile produced in Santo Antão uses eight plastic bottles and they are processed in this innovative recycling factory installed in Penedo. The factory directly employs 5 people and indirectly support many more that collect and deliver plastics from throughout the island, and have an installed capacity to produce up to 24.000 tiles made of plastic with different patterns. The project was promoted by Maria Segredo and the foundation “Amigos do Paúl” in the Netherlands, and was financed by the Dutch Cooperation through the University of TuDelf in Rotterdam.

In November 2018, the factory begun to supply local market with the plastic-made tiles. For the moment, the factory is only recycling “PET” material and producing 20x20 tiles for the construction industry and some decorative material. The acceptance now is good and the orders are increasing rapidly. Each box with 24 tiles costs 3,000 CVE (around 27 Euros) and the company is also exporting the product to the Netherlands, through a partner in that European country.
The project has awarded an ecological merit medal from the Municipality of Paúl.

On a daily basis, the company removes about 25 kilos of plastics from the environment and, in two years, has recycled more than 20 tons of garbage and produced more than 2,000 tiles, which are sold in the domestic market and also abroad. For the moment, the factory is only recycling PET material, but they have stored a large amount of plastic bags for “future experiences”.

Hirondino Silva, manager of the factory, says “often people come here and ask us for plastic bottles, because they say they can no longer find them anymore in the streets.” That’s the sign that our environment is cleaner"" he added. Santo Antão is benefiting from an environment more and more free from used plastic bottles, which are now harder to find.

To get all the plastic material they need, the factory promotes collection in hotels and restaurants throughout the island. Individuals and families are also gathering plastic bottles in their homes and neighborhood to deliver in the factory, and the company pays for it. There is a local young man that promotes plastic collection in the municipal waste landfill and in public gatherings and celebrations. There is also a focal point for plastic collection in the neighbor island São Vicente. Anyone who wants to send plastic to Penedo can reach the company through its phone contacts and Facebook page. The company can help with the logistics in sending the material, namely through the municipality environment services.
